title: George Calombaris Hellenic Republic return after MasterChef judge replacement
text:
He's the former MasterChef judge who was axed from the show amid an $8million wage underpayment saga.

And on Wednesday, a terse George Calombaris was spotted barking orders at his Hellenic Republic restaurant staff in Melbourne.

The embattled restaurateur looked strained as he walked around the perimeter of his restaurant with two of his attentive staff members in tow.

What am I paying you for?! A terse George Calombaris, 41, was seen back in his chef outfit barking orders at his Hellenic Republic restaurant staff on Wednesday. George is pictured with two workers

The chef pointed and told his workers exactly what they needed to clean up before heading inside the kitchen.

He wore black trousers, sneakers and a personalised apron with his initials 'GC' in gold and the logo.

The apron was also emblazoned with the log for his other restaurant The Press Club.

Stressed? The chef pointed and told his workers exactly what they needed to clean up before heading inside the kitchen

He means business! He wore black trousers, sneakers and a personalised apron with his initials 'GC' in gold and the logo

Rough year: It's no secret George has had a stressful few months

It's no secret George has had a stressful few months.

George lost his lucrative job as a MasterChef judge in July, which saw him earn a salary in excess of $1 million.

The original trio of George, Matt Preston and Gary Mehigan reportedly walked away from the program after Channel Ten refused to give them a pay rise.

Under the pump: George lost his lucrative job as a MasterChef judge in July, which saw him earn a salary in excess of $1 million

Done after a decade: Gary Mehigan (left), Matt Preston (right) and George Calombaris have wrapped up their judge and hosting duties on MasterChef Australia after 10 years on the show

At the time, George was also facing controversy for underpaying his restaurant staff by nearly $8 million between 2011 and 2017.

In a statement - which avoided mentioning Calombaris' scandal - Ten's CEO Paul Anderson claimed the decision to axe the three judges came after months of failed negotiations.

Mr Anderson said: 'Despite months of negotiations, Ten has not been able to reach a commercial agreement that was satisfactory to Matt, Gary and George.

'We would like to thank Gary, George and Matt for their contribution over the past 11 years.'
